en:
This acorn lekythos perfectly fits the description of two lekythoi found
      together in Attika, once known in a private collection in Athens, reported as seen by Krte in
      the winter of 1877-1878. It is unclear whether the two were exact duplicates, whether both
      were labelled, and if so, which one eventually came into the collection at the Louvre. They
      have become conflated in bibliographies, although here I list separately the bibliography for
      the "once Athens,"" citations that either pre-date the Louvre acquisition (?), or otherwise
      ignore it.

A female figure, perhaps Hygieia, standing near profile to the right,
      wearing a peplos, a short pony tail, a black band necklace, and disk earrings, holds a box in
      her left hand, and holds her right hand at waist level; a female figure, perhaps Peitho,
      standing 3/4-view to the right, with her weight on her left leg, wearing a sleeveless,
      high-belted chiton, holds a sprig of vegetation in her left hand, and points her right hand to
      Tyche (?); a winged Eros, crouching 3/4-view to the right, crowns the female figure to his
      right, possibly Tyche, seated on a stool 3/4-view to the left, wearing a sleeved chiton, a
      himation around her legs, a short pony tail, a black band necklace, and black hoop earrings;
      she tilts her head back, holds her left arm at her side, and raises her right hand in front of
      her face; a female figure, perhaps Harmonia, standing 3/4-view to the left, wearing a sleeved
      chiton, a himation draped over her left shoulder, a kekryphylon, a beaded necklace, and
      dotted-disk earrings, holds her left hand at waist level, and raises her right hand in front
      of her face.

According to Beazley, the labels identifying these characters are modern. As all,
      with the possible exception of Tyche, are paralleled in contemporary vase paintings, they are
      believable, although on the basis of iconographic parallels it is more likely that the seated
      female figure is Aphrodite, and that the female figure behind her (to the right) is
      Peitho.

<bibl>LIMC</bibl>, 7.248 s.v. Peitho no. 54 (N. Icard-Gianolio);
      <bibl>Add2</bibl>, 364; <bibl>Burn 1987</bibl>, 114 MM 109 pl. 14c-e;
      <bibl>LIMC</bibl>, 2.150 s.v. Aphrodite no. 1563, pl. 152 (A. Delivorrias);
      <bibl>Lezzi-Hafter 1976</bibl>, 48, 117, O 22, pl. 166a-b;
      <bibl>EAA</bibl> 7 (1966) 1040 s.v. Tyche (J.G. Szilgyi); <bibl>Hamdorf
      1964</bibl> 100 no. 325b; <bibl>Papadaki 1960</bibl> 123.
